hints: A class of vertebrates characterized by the presence of mammary glands.
They have hair or fur and are warm-blooded.
A cold-blooded vertebrate animal.
Includes snakes, lizards, crocodiles, turtles, and tortoises.
A cold-blooded vertebrate that lives both on land and in water.
Typically includes frogs, toads, newts, and salamanders.
Relating to birds.
The class of warm-blooded vertebrates with feathers and wings.
An invertebrate animal with an exoskeleton, a segmented body, and jointed appendages.
Includes insects, arachnids, and crustaceans.
A soft-bodied invertebrate animal.
Often has a hard external shell, like snails, clams, and octopuses.
An animal with a backbone or spinal column.
Includes fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals.
An animal without a backbone or spinal column.
The majority of all animal species are this type.
An animal that feeds on plants.
Examples include cows, deer, and rabbits.
An animal that feeds on other animals.
Lions, tigers, and wolves are examples.
An animal that eats both plants and animals.
Humans and bears are examples.
The branch of science concerned with the bodily structure of humans, animals, and other living organisms.
The study of the physical form of an organism.
The branch of biology that deals with the normal functions of living organisms and their parts.
The study of how an organism's body works.
The branch of biology that deals with the relations of organisms to one another and to their physical surroundings.
The study of ecosystems.
The branch of science concerned with classification.
The naming and classification of living organisms.
A principal taxonomic category that ranks above species and below family.
The first part of a scientific name, like 'Homo' in Homo sapiens.
The basic unit of classification and a taxonomic rank.
A group of organisms that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring.
The process of transformation from an immature form to an adult form in two or more distinct stages.
A caterpillar transforming into a butterfly is an example.
A state of inactivity and metabolic depression in endotherms.
A deep sleep that some animals undergo in winter.
Prolonged dormancy of an animal during a hot or dry period.
Similar to hibernation, but for summer.
Seasonal movement of animals from one region to another.
Often done for feeding or breeding.
An animal that hunts other animals for food.
A lion hunting a zebra is an example.
An animal that is hunted and killed by another for food.
The zebra is this to the lion.
A close and long-term interaction between two different biological species.
Can be mutualistic, commensalistic, or parasitic.
An organism that lives in or on another organism and benefits by deriving nutrients at the host's expense.
Includes ticks, fleas, and tapeworms.
An organism that harbors a parasite or mutualistic species.
The organism being lived in or on.
The role and position a species has in its environment.
Describes how an organism interacts with its ecosystem.
A change or the process of change by which an organism or species becomes better suited to its environment.
Camouflage is an example.
The tendency toward a relatively stable equilibrium between interdependent elements.
The regulation of an organism's internal environment.
The process that allows the body to maintain its core internal temperature.
The control of body temperature.
An animal that is dependent on external sources of body heat.
Commonly known as 'cold-blooded' animals.
An animal that is dependent on or capable of the internal generation of heat.
Commonly known as 'warm-blooded' animals.
A large group of animals, especially hoofed mammals, that live and feed together.
A group of elephants or cows.
A group of birds.
A group of sheep or goats.
A large number of fish or other aquatic animals swimming together.
A group of dolphins or whales can also be called this.
A large group of insects.
A large or dense group of flying insects.
A group of organisms of the same species living closely together.
A group of ants, bees, or penguins.
A group of lions.
The social unit of lions.
A group of wild animals, especially wolves, hunting together.
A group of dogs or wolves.
A small herd of seals, whales, or other marine mammals.
A group of dolphins or porpoises.
A part of the brain that plays an important role in motor control.
It is located at the back of the skull.
The principal and most anterior part of the brain.
It is responsible for the integration of complex sensory and neural functions.
The network of nerve cells and fibers that transmits nerve impulses between parts of the body.
It is the control center of the body.
The system that circulates blood and lymph through the body.
The heart is the main organ of this system.
The set of organs responsible for gas exchange.
Lungs and gills are part of this system.
The system of organs that takes in food and digests it to extract energy.
The stomach and intestines are key parts of this system.
The system that removes waste from the body.
Kidneys are the main organs of this system.
The framework of the body, consisting of bones and other connective tissues.
It provides structure and protection for the body.
An organ system consisting of skeletal, smooth, and cardiac muscles.
It permits movement of the body.
The biological system of an organism used for sexual reproduction.
It includes organs like the testes and ovaries.
The collection of glands that produce hormones.
It regulates metabolism, growth, and development.
A network of tissues and organs that help rid the body of toxins, waste and other unwanted materials.
It's a part of the immune system.
The way in which two things affect each other.
The effect of a predator on a prey population.
Any member of the biological family Hominidae.
This family includes humans, chimpanzees, gorillas, and orangutans.
An animal that walks on two legs.
Humans and ostriches are examples.
An animal that walks on four legs.
Dogs, cats, and horses are examples.
Animals that lay eggs.
Birds and most reptiles are this type.
Animals that give birth to live young.
Most mammals are this type.
The active immature form of an insect, especially one that differs greatly from the adult.
A caterpillar is a type of this.
An insect in its inactive immature form between larva and adult.
The stage of a butterfly inside a chrysalis.
A group that comprises all animals having a body composed of cells differentiated into tissues and organs.
All living things except bacteria, protists, fungi, and plants are this.
A specialized cell transmitting nerve impulses.
A nerve cell.
A structure in the eye that is sensitive to light.
Rods and cones are examples.
A sensory receptor that transduces a chemical signal into a cell signal.
Responsible for the sense of smell and taste.
A sensory receptor that responds to mechanical pressure or distortion.
These are found in the skin for touch.
A sensory receptor that responds to changes in temperature.
These detect heat and cold.
The maintenance of constant osmotic pressure in the fluids of an organism.
The regulation of water and salt balance.
The remains or impression of a prehistoric organism preserved in petrified form.
Provides evidence of past life.
The scientific study of life that existed prior to, and sometimes including, the start of the Holocene Epoch.
The study of fossils.
The scientific and objective study of animal behavior.
The study of animal behavior in their natural habitats.
The study of heredity and the variation of inherited characteristics.
The study of genes.
A diploid cell resulting from the fusion of two haploid gametes.
A fertilized egg.
An unborn or unhatched offspring in the process of development.
The stage of development after the zygote.
Relating to a larva.
The immature stage of an insect.
A fully grown or developed animal.
The final stage of an organism's life cycle.
A unit of heredity that is transferred from a parent to offspring.
A sequence of DNA or RNA that codes for a protein.
One of two or more alternative forms of a gene that arise by mutation.
Different versions of a gene.
A distinguishing characteristic or quality.
Eye color or height are examples.
A gene that is always expressed.
It will show up even if only one copy is present.
A gene that is only expressed when two copies are present.
It is masked by a dominant gene.
The set of observable characteristics of an individual.
The physical appearance of an organism.
The genetic makeup of an organism.
The set of genes that an organism has.
The offspring of two animals or plants of different species or varieties.
A mule is a cross between a horse and a donkey.
The changing of the structure of a gene.
A permanent change in DNA.
The process by which different kinds of living organisms are thought to have developed and diversified from earlier forms.
The change in a population over time.
The process whereby organisms better adapted to their environment tend to survive and produce more offspring.
Survival of the fittest.
The intentional breeding of plants or animals to produce desirable traits.
The process used in dog breeding.
The state or process of a species, family, or larger group being or becoming extinct.
The complete disappearance of a species.
Relating to or caused by a fungus.
This type of infection can affect animals.
An animal that carries pollen from one plant to another.
Bees and butterflies are examples.
The production and emission of light by a living organism.
Fireflies and some deep-sea fish exhibit this.
The use of sound waves to locate objects.
Used by bats and dolphins to navigate.
A species that is at risk of becoming extinct.
The giant panda is an example of this status.
A species likely to become endangered in the near future.
One level below endangered on the conservation status list.
The action of conserving something.
The act of protecting wildlife and their habitats.
The action of preserving and protecting something.
The protection of animals from extinction.
The variety of life in the world or in a particular habitat or ecosystem.
The number and variety of different species in an area.
The natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism.
The place where an animal lives.
A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.
Includes both living and non-living things.
A relationship between two organisms in which one benefits and the other is not affected.
Barnacles on a whale is an example.
A relationship between two organisms in which both benefit.
The relationship between a bee and a flower.
A relationship between two organisms in which one benefits at the expense of the other.
Ticks on a dog is an example.
A close and long-term interaction between two different biological species.
A general term for these types of relationships.
The preying of one animal on others.
Hunting and killing for food.
The eating of plants, especially by animals.
The feeding of a deer on grass.
The eating of meat.
The diet of a lion or wolf.
A chemical substance produced and released into the environment by an animal.
Used to communicate with other members of its species.
A structure that is similar in different species of common ancestry.
The forelimbs of humans, bats, and whales.
A structure that has a similar function but different evolutionary origin.
The wings of a butterfly and the wings of a bird.
An organ or part of an organism that is reduced in size and function over time.
The human appendix is an example.
The branch of biology concerned with the study of embryos.
The study of the development of an organism.
The study of the form and structure of organisms.
The study of an animal's physical appearance.
The study of the geographical distribution of plants and animals.
The study of where species are found on Earth.
Any of the subfamily Homininae, which includes humans and their extinct ancestors.
A more specific term for the human lineage after the split from chimpanzees.
The scientific study of bones.
A branch of anatomy.
The study of fossil footprints and tracks.
The study of trace fossils.
The scientific study of birds.
A branch of zoology.
The scientific study of mammals.
A branch of zoology.
The branch of zoology concerned with the study of amphibians and reptiles.
Includes the study of frogs, snakes, and lizards.
The branch of zoology that deals with fish.
The study of fish.
The scientific study of insects.
A branch of zoology.
The scientific study of arachnids, such as spiders and scorpions.
A sub-discipline of entomology.
The scientific study of ants.
A sub-discipline of entomology.
The branch of marine mammal science that studies whales, dolphins, and porpoises.
The study of cetaceans.
The scientific study of primates.
Includes the study of monkeys, apes, and lemurs.
An animal that feeds on insects.
Ant-eaters and some shrews are examples.
The study of bird eggs.
A specialized branch of ornithology.
A phylum or group of phyla that comprises single-celled microscopic animals.
Includes amoebas and ciliates.
A worm of the large phylum Nematoda.
Also known as a roundworm.
A protozoan parasite.
The causative agent of malaria.
An oval or round object laid by a female bird, reptile, amphibian, fish, or invertebrate.
Contains a developing embryo.
A young animal that has recently hatched from an egg.
A newborn bird or turtle.
A young animal, not yet an adult.
An immature animal.
A term for an animal that is relatively mature and mobile from the moment of birth or hatching.
Examples include chicks and foals.
A term for an animal that is helpless at birth or hatching and requires parental care.
Examples include human babies and kittens.
The process of carrying or being carried in the womb between conception and birth.
The period of pregnancy in mammals.
The process of an animal, especially a bird, sitting on eggs to keep them warm.
The period of time before an egg hatches.
Relating to the behavior of an animal in defending its territory.
Defending a specific area from other animals.
The behavior of male and female animals of the same species.
Used to attract a mate.
The practice of having a single partner during a breeding season or for life.
Penguins and beavers are examples.
The practice of having multiple partners during a breeding season.
Many species of mammals and birds exhibit this.
The behavior of a parent to their offspring.
Includes protecting, feeding, and teaching young.
A large naturally occurring community of flora and fauna occupying a major habitat.
Examples include the tundra, desert, or tropical rainforest.
A region of transition between two biological communities.
A zone where two habitats meet, such as a forest and a grassland.
A species on which other species in an ecosystem largely depend.
If it were removed, the ecosystem would change drastically.
The quality or state of being omnivorous.
The ability to eat both plants and animals.
The killing and eating of other animals for food.
The act of a predator hunting its prey.
An organism that lives in a relationship where it benefits and the other organism is not affected.
The barnacle in the commensalism example.
An organism in a relationship where both organisms benefit.
The bee in the mutualism example.
Relating to or caused by a parasite.
A lifestyle where one organism lives off another.
An innate mechanism in an organism that controls the periodicity of its activities.
A circadian rhythm.
A natural, internal process that regulates the sleepâ€“wake cycle and repeats roughly every 24 hours.
An internal biological clock.
Active during the day.
Humans and squirrels are examples.
Active during the night.
Bats and owls are examples.
Active during the twilight hours of dawn and dusk.
Rabbits and deer are examples.
Plankton consisting of small animals and the immature stages of larger animals.
Microscopic animals in the ocean.
Plankton consisting of microscopic plants.
Forms the base of the marine food chain.
A type of protozoan characterized by the presence of cilia.
These use tiny hairs for movement.
A cell or organism with one or more whip-like appendages.
These use a flagellum for movement.
A single-celled protozoan that can change its shape.
It moves by extending and retracting pseudopods.
One of two forms of cnidarians.
A sessile form, like a coral or sea anemone.
One of two forms of cnidarians.
A free-swimming form, like a jellyfish.
A stinging organelle found in cnidarians.
Used for defense and to capture prey.
The opening in the head of an animal through which food is taken in.
Used for communication and breathing.
The membrane-lined cavity behind the nose and mouth.
Part of the throat in vertebrates.
The part of the alimentary canal that connects the throat to the stomach.
Also known as the food pipe.
The internal organ in which the major part of the digestion of food occurs.
A muscular bag that holds and breaks down food.
A long, continuous tube running from the stomach to the anus.
Where most nutrient absorption occurs.
A large glandular organ in the abdomen.
It produces bile and detoxifies blood.
A large gland behind the stomach.
It secretes digestive enzymes and hormones like insulin.
One of a pair of organs in the abdominal cavity of vertebrates.
It filters waste from the blood.
A hollow muscular organ that pumps blood through the circulatory system.
The central organ of the circulatory system.
Each of the pair of organs in the chest of vertebrates.
Used for breathing and gas exchange.
The respiratory organ of fish and some other aquatic animals.
Used to extract oxygen from water.
An organ of soft nervous tissue contained in the skull of vertebrates.
The center of the nervous system.
An internal or external framework of bone, cartilage, or other rigid material.
The framework that supports and protects an animal's body.
A band or bundle of fibrous tissue in a human or animal body.
It has the ability to contract and produce movement.
A firm, flexible connective tissue.
Found in the nose, ears, and joints.
A flexible but inelastic cord of strong fibrous collagen tissue.
It attaches muscle to bone.
A short band of tough, flexible, fibrous connective tissue.
It connects two bones or cartilages or holds together a joint.
A point at which two or more things are joined.
The connection between two bones.
The series of vertebrae extending from the skull to the pelvis.
Also known as the backbone.
Each of the series of small bones forming the backbone.
The individual bones of the spine.
A framework of bone or cartilage enclosing the brain.
The bony part of the head.
The bony framework of the chest.
It protects the heart and lungs.
The large bony framework at the base of the spine.
It supports the trunk and connects to the legs.
The bone of the thigh.
The longest and strongest bone in the body.
The bone of the upper arm.
It runs from the shoulder to the elbow.
One of the two large bones of the forearm.
It extends from the elbow to the wrist.
The other of the two large bones of the forearm.
It is on the side of the pinky finger.
The inner and typically larger of the two bones between the knee and the ankle.
The shinbone.
The outer and typically smaller of the two bones between the knee and the ankle.
It runs parallel to the tibia.
The group of small bones between the forearm and the hand.
The wrist bones.
A cluster of seven bones in each foot.
The ankle bones.
Any of the five bones of the hand.
They connect the wrist to the fingers.
Any of the five bones of the foot.
They connect the ankle to the toes.
The bones that make up the fingers and toes.
Three in each finger and two in each thumb.
An action in response to some influence or stimulus.
The process of a muscle contracting.
The involuntary constriction and relaxation of the muscles of the intestine or another canal.
It creates wavelike movements that push the contents forward.
The process in which a gastrula develops from a blastula by the inward migration of some of its cells.
A stage in early embryonic development.
The process in which the neural plate becomes the neural tube.
A stage of embryonic development that forms the central nervous system.
The division of cells in the early embryo.
The series of mitotic divisions that the zygote undergoes.
An early stage of an embryo.
A hollow ball of cells.
An embryo at the stage following the blastula.
Characterized by the formation of three germ layers.
The three primary layers of cells in an embryo.
Includes the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
The outermost of the three primary germ layers.
It gives rise to the nervous system and skin.
The middle of the three primary germ layers.
It gives rise to the muscles, skeleton, and circulatory system.
The innermost of the three primary germ layers.
It gives rise to the gut, lungs, and liver.
The type of egg laid by reptiles, birds, and monotremes.
It is a shelled egg containing a fluid-filled sac for the embryo.
A bird's feathers collectively.
The entire coat of feathers of a bird.
A young bird that has just acquired its flight feathers.
A young bird ready to leave the nest.
The process of shedding an old exoskeleton or feathers.
A snake shedding its skin.
Chemical messengers that travel through the bloodstream.
Produced by the endocrine glands.
An organ in the human or animal body that secretes particular chemical substances.
The pituitary and thyroid are examples.
A large ductless gland in the neck.
It secretes hormones regulating growth and metabolism.
The master gland of the endocrine system.
A small gland at the base of the brain that controls other glands.
A pair of endocrine glands located above the kidneys.
They produce hormones like adrenaline.
A hormone produced in the pancreas.
It regulates the amount of glucose in the blood.
A hormone produced by the pancreas.
It raises the concentration of glucose in the bloodstream.
A steroid hormone produced by the adrenal glands.
Often called the 'stress hormone'.
A hormone secreted by the adrenal glands.
The 'fight-or-flight' hormone.
A hormone secreted by the pineal gland.
It helps regulate sleep and wake cycles.
A hormone that acts as a neurotransmitter.
Known as the 'love hormone'.
A hormone that regulates the body's water balance.
Also known as antidiuretic hormone (ADH).
The main hormone produced by the thyroid gland.
It plays a crucial role in metabolism.
A hormone produced by the pituitary gland.
Primarily associated with lactation in mammals.
A group of steroid hormones that promote the development and maintenance of female characteristics.
The primary female sex hormone.
A steroid hormone that stimulates development of male secondary sexual characteristics.
The primary male sex hormone.
A mature haploid male or female germ cell which is able to unite with another of the opposite sex in sexual reproduction.
A sperm or an egg.
Having a single set of unpaired chromosomes.
The state of a gamete.
Containing two complete sets of chromosomes, one from each parent.
The state of a zygote or a somatic cell.
A type of cell division that results in four daughter cells each with half the number of chromosomes of the parent cell.
Used to produce gametes.
A type of cell division that results in two identical daughter cells.
Used for growth and repair.
Any cell of a living organism other than the reproductive cells.
A body cell.
A genus of single-celled flagellate protists.
Often used in biology classes to study cell structure.
An appendage that helps in locomotion.
A type of pseudopod.
A phylum of aquatic invertebrate animals.
Includes jellyfish, sea anemones, and corals.
An arthropod of the large class Crustacea.
Includes crabs, lobsters, shrimp, and barnacles.
A fibrous substance consisting of polysaccharides.
The main component of the exoskeleton of arthropods.
The hard upper shell of a turtle, crab, or other crustacean.
A protective shell.
The fused head and thorax of spiders and other chelicerate arthropods.
The body part of a lobster that includes the head.
The part of the body of a vertebrate containing the digestive organs.
The belly.
An arthropod of the class Arachnida.
Includes spiders, scorpions, mites, and ticks.
A rigid external skeleton.
The skeleton of an insect or crab.
An internal skeleton.
The skeleton of a vertebrate.
A genus of small fresh-water animals of the phylum Cnidaria.
It has a tubular body and can regenerate itself.
A free-swimming marine animal with a bell-shaped body and tentacles.
A type of cnidarian.
A marine invertebrate of the phylum Cnidaria.
It typically forms large reefs.
A large phylum of worms with segmented bodies.
Includes earthworms and leeches.
A segmented worm.
An earthworm is an example.
A phylum of worms that includes roundworms.
They are non-segmented worms.
A phylum of worms that includes flatworms.
Tapeworms and flukes are examples.
A phylum of invertebrates with soft, unsegmented bodies.
Includes snails, slugs, clams, and octopuses.
A class of mollusks.
Includes snails and slugs.
An aquatic mollusk that has a compressed body enclosed within a hinged shell.
Clams, oysters, and mussels are examples.
A class of mollusks characterized by having a prominent head and a set of arms or tentacles.
Includes squids, octopuses, and cuttlefish.
A phylum of marine animals.
Includes starfish, sea urchins, and sea cucumbers.
A marine invertebrate with five or more arms radiating from a central disk.
Also known as a sea star.
A small, spiny, globular echinoderm.
Found in all oceans.
The phylum of animals that have a notochord.
Includes all vertebrates.
A flexible rod that supports a chordate's back.
A primitive spine.
Openings that connect the pharynx with the outside.
A feature of all chordates at some stage of development.
A posterior elongation of the body.
A feature of all chordates at some stage of development.
A jawless fish.
Known for producing copious amounts of slime.
A jawless fish with a toothed, funnel-like sucking mouth.
A parasitic fish.
Having a skeleton composed of cartilage rather than bone.
Sharks and rays are this type of fish.
A long-bodied predatory fish.
Known for its sharp teeth and cartilaginous skeleton.
A cartilaginous fish with a flattened body and winglike pectoral fins.
Includes stingrays and manta rays.
A fish with a skeleton of bone.
The majority of fish species.
A type of freshwater fish that has both gills and a primitive lung.
It can breathe air.
A lobe-finned fish that was once thought to be extinct.
Considered a 'living fossil'.
A cold-blooded vertebrate that lives both on land and in water.
Includes frogs, toads, newts, and salamanders.
A limbless, burrowing amphibian.
Resembles a snake or worm.
An amphibian with a tail.
Includes newts and salamanders.
A tail-less amphibian.
Includes frogs and toads.
A class of cold-blooded vertebrates.
Includes snakes, lizards, turtles, and alligators.
A major group of reptiles including dinosaurs and birds.
A group of 'ruling reptiles'.
A group of reptiles that dominated terrestrial ecosystems for over 160 million years.
T-Rex is an example.
A reptile of the order Crocodilia.
Includes alligators, crocodiles, and gharials.
A reptile of the order Testudines.
Includes turtles, tortoises, and terrapins.
The largest order of reptiles.
Includes lizards, snakes, and amphisbaenians.
The suborder of snakes.
A group of legless reptiles.
The class of birds.
A group of warm-blooded, egg-laying vertebrates.
A mammal that lays eggs.
The platypus and echidna are examples.
A mammal of an order whose members are characterized by the pouch in which they carry their young.
Kangaroos and koalas are examples.
A mammal that has a placenta for nourishing the fetus.
Humans, whales, and dogs are examples.
A mammal of the order Primates.
Includes lemurs, monkeys, apes, and humans.
A mammal of the order Rodentia.
Includes mice, rats, squirrels, and beavers.
The order of mammals that includes bats.
The only mammals capable of sustained flight.
The order of marine mammals that includes whales, dolphins, and porpoises.
A group of aquatic mammals.
An order of mammals that includes cats, dogs, bears, and seals.
These are primarily meat-eaters.
An order of even-toed ungulates.
Includes pigs, hippos, deer, and cattle.
An order of odd-toed ungulates.
Includes horses, rhinoceroses, and tapirs.
An order of mammals that includes elephants.
Characterized by a long trunk or proboscis.
An order of aquatic mammals.
Includes manatees and dugongs.
An order of mammals found in the Americas.
Includes sloths, armadillos, and anteaters.
An order of mammals that includes rabbits, hares, and pikas.
Often mistaken for rodents.
An aquatic mammal of the order Cetacea.
Includes whales and dolphins.
A suborder of carnivorous marine mammals.
Includes seals, sea lions, and walruses.
A mammal that lays eggs.
Platypus and echidna are examples.
